t: Luke 19
Jesus Visits Zacchaeus
He*p entered Jericho and was passing through.
There was a man named Zacchaeus who was a chief tax collector, and he was rich.
He was trying to see who Jesus was, but he was not able because of the crowd, since he was a short man.
So running ahead, he climbed up a sycamore tree to see Jesus, since he was about to pass that way.
When Jesus came to the place, he looked up and said to him, “Zacchaeus,*r hurry*r and*r come*r down*r because*r today*r it*r is*r necessary*r for*r me*r to*r stay*r at*r your*r house.”*r
So*p he quickly came down and welcomed him joyfully.
All who saw it began to complain, “He’s gone to stay with a sinful man.”
But*p Zacchaeus stood there and said to the Lord, “Look, I’ll give half of my possessions to the poor, Lord. And if I have extorted anything from anyone, I’ll pay back four times as much.”
“Today*rp salvation*r has*r come*r to*r this*r house,”*r Jesus told him, “because*r he*r too*r is*r a*r son*r of*r Abraham.*r
For*r the*r Son*r of*r Man*r has*r come*r to*r seek*r and*r to*r save*r the*r lost.”*r
The Parable of the Ten Minas
As*p they were listening to this, he went on to tell a parable because he was near Jerusalem, and they thought the kingdom of God was going to appear right away.
Therefore*p he said, “A*r nobleman*r traveled*r to*r a*r far*r country*r to*r receive*r for*r himself*r authority*r to*r be*r king*r and*r then*r to*r return.*r
He*r called*r ten*r of*r his*r servants,*r gave*r them*r ten*r minas,*r and*r told*r them,*r ‘Engage*r in*r business*r until*r I*r come*r back.’*r
“But*rp his*r subjects*r hated*r him*r and*r sent*r a*r delegation*r after*r him,*r saying,*r ‘We*r don’t*r want*r this*r man*r to*r rule*r over*r us.’*r

“At*rp his*r return,*r having*r received*r the*r authority*r to*r be*r king,*r he*r summoned*r those*r servants*r he*r had*r given*r the*r money*r to,*r so*r that*r he*r could*r find*r out*r how*r much*r they*r had*r made*r in*r business.*r
The*r first*r came*r forward*r and*r said,*r ‘Master,*r your*r mina*r has*r earned*r ten*r more*r minas.’*r
“‘Well*rp done,*r good*r servant! ’*r he*r told*r him.*r ‘Because*r you*r have*r been*r faithful*r in*r a*r very*r small*r matter,*r have*r authority*r over*r ten*r towns.’*r
“The*rp second*r came*r and*r said,*r ‘Master,*r your*r mina*r has*r made*r five*r minas.’*r
“So*rp he*r said*r to*r him,*r ‘You*r will*r be*r over*r five*r towns.’*r
“And*rp another*r came*r and*r said,*r ‘Master,*r here*r is*r your*r mina.*r I*r have*r kept*r it*r safe*r in*r a*r cloth*r
because*r I*r was*r afraid*r of*r you*r since*r you’re*r a*r harsh*r man:*r you*r collect*r what*r you*r didn’t*r deposit*r and*r reap*r what*r you*r didn’t*r sow.’*r

“He*rp told*r him,*r ‘I*r will*r condemn*r you*r by*r what*r you*r have*r said,*r you*r evil*r servant!*r If*r you*r knew*r I*r was*r a*r harsh*r man,*r collecting*r what*r I*r didn’t*r deposit*r and*r reaping*r what*r I*r didn’t*r sow,*r
why,*r then,*r didn’t*r you*r put*r my*r money*r in*r the*r bank?*r And*r when*r I*r returned,*r I*r would*r have*r collected*r it*r with*r interest.’*r
So*r he*r said*r to*r those*r standing*r there,*r ‘Take*r the*r mina*r away*r from*r him*r and*r give*r it*r to*r the*r one*r who*r has*r ten*r minas.’*r
“But*rp they*r said*r to*r him,*r ‘Master,*r he*r has*r ten*r minas.’*r
“‘I*rp tell*r you,*r that*r to*r everyone*r who*r has,*r more*r will*r be*r given;*r and*r from*r the*r one*r who*r does*r not*r have,*r even*r what*r he*r does*r have*r will*r be*r taken*r away.*r
But*r bring*r here*r these*r enemies*r of*r mine,*r who*r did*r not*r want*r me*r to*r rule*r over*r them,*r and*r slaughter*r them*r in*r my*r presence.’”*r
The Triumphal Entry
When*p he had said these things, he went on ahead, going up to Jerusalem.
As he approached Bethphage and Bethany, at the place called the Mount of Olives, he sent two of the disciples

and said, “Go*r into*r the*r village*r ahead*r of*r you.*r As*r you*r enter*r it,*r you*r will*r find*r a*r colt*r tied*r there,*r on*r which*r no*r one*r has*r ever*r sat.*r Untie*r it*r and*r bring*r it.*r
If*r anyone*r asks*r you,*r ‘Why*r are*r you*r untying*r it? ’*r say*r this:*r ‘The*r Lord*r needs*r it.’”*r
So*p those who were sent left and found it just as he had told them.
As they were untying the colt, its owners said to them, “Why are you untying the colt?”
“The*p Lord needs it,” they said.
Then they brought it to Jesus, and after throwing their clothes on the colt, they helped Jesus get on it.
As he was going along, they were spreading their clothes on the road.
Now he came near the path down the Mount of Olives, and the whole crowd of the disciples began to praise God joyfully with a loud voice for all the miracles they had seen:
Blessed*ipn is*i the*i King*i who*i comes*i in*iln the*i name*i of*i the*i Lord.*i Peace*ln in heaven and*ln glory in the highest heaven!
Some*p of the Pharisees from the crowd told him, “Teacher, rebuke your disciples.”
He*p answered, “I*r tell*r you,*r if*r they*r were*r to*r keep*r silent,*r the*r stones*r would*r cry*r out.”*r
Jesus’s Love for Jerusalem
As*p he approached and saw the city, he wept for it,
saying, “If*r you*r knew*r this*r day*r what*r would*r bring*r peace -*r but*r now*r it*r is*r hidden*r from*r your*r eyes.*r
For*r the*r days*r will*r come*r on*r you*r when*r your*r enemies*r will*r build*r a*r barricade*r around*r you,*r surround*r you,*r and*r hem*r you*r in*r on*r every*r side.*r

They*r will*r crush*r you*r and*r your*r children*r among*r you*r to*r the*r ground,*r and*r they*r will*r not*r leave*r one*r stone*r on*r another*r in*r your*r midst,*r because*r you*r did*r not*r recognize*r the*r time*r when*r God*r visited*r you.”*r
Cleansing the Temple
He*p went into the temple and began to throw out those who were selling,
and he said, “It*r is*r written,*r my*ir house*ir will*ir be*ir a*ir house*ir of*ir prayer,*ir but*r you*r have*r made*r it*r a*ir den*ir of*ir thieves!”*ir
Every*p day he was teaching in the temple. The chief priests, the scribes, and the leaders of the people were looking for a way to kill him,
but they could not find a way to do it, because all the people were captivated by what they heard.
